RADIO SYSTEMS INSPECTION FOLLOWING LIGHINING STRIKES
1.
2.
GENERAL
OPERATIONAL CHECK OF RADIO SYSTEMS FOLLOWING A
LIGHTNING STRIKE
INSPECTION OF SYSTEM AFFECTED BY LIGHTNING STRIKE
GENERAL
The radio installations must be thoroughly checked whenever an aircraft
had had a lightning strike or severe static discharge.
the inspection will
The extent of
incident.
depend upon the circunstances surrounding the
B.
The flight crew should be de-briefed with regard to the conditions
existing during and after the
"strike".
Ref. OD Manual
If the flight crew is unavailable,
publ. 45.21.10.
fully to extract whatever information is available.
the aircraft log should be read care-
C.
A visual check from the ground of all antennas,
dischargers,
etc., must be made to determine if any physical damage
has occured.
D. An operational check of all radio Communications and Navigation systems
must be made by a qualified
mechanic or flight
crew member, per
Part 2 of this publication.
If all radio systems operate normally and
no in-flight malfunctions were reported, no further checks are required.
E.
If a radio system mal-function was reported by the flight crew or
detected during the operational check, a detailed inspection of the
affected system or systems must be made per Part 3 of this publication.
F.
After completion of the required checks an entry must be made in the
aircraft log stating that an
"After Lightning Strike"
was made, noting any corrective
"ion.
Operational Check
G.
H.
Any component which has been reil ied from an aireraft as a result of a
lightning strike or static discharge must have a Blue Engineering
Evaluation, Iag, form 9242-3161 filled out and attached.
If a malfunction exists in a system which is not required for dispatch
of the aircraft from a particular station per Maintenance Manual
publication 1-5-0, repairs may be continued to another station provided
all safety requirements are satisfied.
